title: Confusing error message
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=efe6e56404094abbfbc3c1183587fe23

```rust
use std::collections::HashMap;

fn f<'a>(_: &'a mut HashMap<usize, &'a usize>) {}

fn main() {
    let mut scores = HashMap::new();
    f(&mut scores);
    let _ = &mut scores;
    // or let t = &scores;
}
```

I expected to see this happen: 

I expect compiling succeeds or give readable error message.

Instead, this happened:

```
     1     Compiling rust_try v0.1.0 (/Users/ctsinon/Projects/StaticAnalysis/rust_try)
     2  error[E0499]: cannot borrow `scores` as mutable more than once at a time
     3   --> src/main.rs:8:13
     4    |
     5  7 |     f(&mut scores);
     6    |       ----------- first mutable borrow occurs here
     7  8 |     let _ = &mut scores;
     8    |             ^^^^^^^^^^^
     9    |             |
    10    |             second mutable borrow occurs here
    11    |             first borrow later used here
       
    12  error: aborting due to previous error
       
    13  For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0499`.
    14  error: could not compile `rust_try`
       
    15  To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

It seems that the code causing the error at line 11 is missing. 

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.54.0 (a178d0322 2021-07-26)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: a178d0322ce20e33eac124758e837cbd80a6f633
commit-date: 2021-07-26
host: x86_64-apple-darwin
release: 1.54.0
LLVM version: 12.0.1
```

And I wonder if anyone can explain why this code can cause a second mutable borrow.

After changing the prototype of `f` to 

```rust
use std::collections::HashMap;

fn f(_: &mut HashMap<usize, &usize>) {}

fn main() {
    let mut scores = HashMap::new();
    f(&mut scores);
    let _ = &mut scores;
    // or let t = &scores;
}
```

the error disappears.

<!--
Include a backtrace in the code block by setting `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` in your
environment. E.g. `RUST_BACKTRACE=1 cargo build`.
-->
